item.title: Ticket #3562 (Some cache adds should be sets) created
item.dc:creator: andy
item.description:
When the data is fresh from the db or another authoritative source, the cache operation should be SET, not ADD.

With ADD you run the risk of innacurate data taking precedence. This has caused nasty issues with plugins on wordpress.com.

Patch attached.

item.title: Ticket #3527 (wp-includes/rss-functions.php function get_rss has a bug) updated
item.dc:creator: foolswisdom
item.description:
Replying to Otto42:

The function immediately above it, wp_rss(), is basically identical except that it also outputs <UL> tags around the list of links, and does not have the same bug. It should probably be modified to call get_rss() to do its actual work, instead of duplicating the code.

If the problem is on trunk and you are able submit a patch. Probably best to create a new ticket, because I start to get confused when there are new problems added later to a ticket.

item.title: Ticket #3548 (Updating permalink structure crashes server) updated
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
There was some discussion on it here too: ​http://wordpress.org/support/topic/99953

I'm not entirely familiar with the way rewriting works (I was highly confused when posting to that thread, and how I thought it worked was wrong), but they're talking about having 1000+ static pages in that thread. From what I can see, the problem could be something in the page_rewrite_rules() function, due to the fact that it has to do this huge loop of array merges and generate_rewrite_rules and so forth, for everything in page_uris.

Of course, having that many static pages is definitely an edge case.

item.title: Ticket #3560 (Seriously! Broken Docking Boxes (dbx)) created
item.dc:creator: Xmion
item.description:
Yeah i think it's about time we fix the broken Docking Boxes (dbx) seriously!, everybody out there trying make admin themes or other stuff get a headheack. The small boxes is perfect but the big once is broken everywhere man.

  • Write Post
  • Write Page
  • Add Link

And whats about useing the "fieldset" why not use fashion divs Instead? aight. The big boxes has white corners and leftstrip now and yeah most people doesn't even see it's broken but anyway why make something half bad when we can make it perfect for everybody i don't see the problem why we shouldn't fix this issue.

Left Top / Title Left Stripe / Content Left Bottom / Bottom

​http://hem.passagen.se/spudi/broken-bdx.png

If somebody ain't wanna fix this issue i can take it on me but i can only send raw php files so somebody else make them to diff or whatever makes you happy for the svn system.

item.title: Ticket #2828 (Ease MySQL4.1 character set configuration) updated
item.dc:creator: tenpura
item.description:
jimisola,

I know what you mean, but there are many issues to consider before we go.

Is it set to UTF-8 by default

It is good for new installation, but possibly harmful for upgrades.

I strongly believe that the encoding used for the database should be a simple setting in the admin interface

This cannot be an option stored in the database. Also, I believe that character set related MySQL system variables should not be easily changeable on running WP. Without proper backup and preparation, users may lose their data. (It is described in #3517)

There is another issue. If a user uses a localization file (MO), changing character set related MySQL system variables on running WP might cause login failure. (See #3442)

I have started writing a helper plugin for this and hopefully release it to the public before WP2.1.

item.title: Ticket #3527 (wp-includes/rss-functions.php function get_rss has a bug) reopened
item.dc:creator: yskin
item.description:
Replying to markjaquith:

Looks fine to me in /branches/2.0/ and /trunk/

In the end of /trunk/wp-includes/rss.php 

function get_rss ($uri, '''$num = 5''') { // Like get posts, but for RSS
     $rss = fetch_rss($url);
     if ( $rss ) {
         $rss->items = array_slice($rss->items, 0, '''$num_items''');
         foreach ($rss->items as $item ) {
             echo "<li>\n";
             echo "<a href='$item[link]' title='$item[description]'>";
             echo htmlentities($item['title']);
             echo "</a><br />\n";
             echo "</li>\n";
         }
         return $posts;
     } else {
         return false;
     }
 }

$num_items should be $num.

This is a typo bug in both 2.0.6 and 2.1

item.dc:creator: foolswisdom
item.description:
Thank you for participating in WordPress!

Please start by including all of your environment info including WordPress version and build?

Please include an example and steps to reproduce the problem.

What is specific to WordPress Mu about the problem? WordPress Mu code is the same as WordPress and only different in a few areas -- this not being one of them. Does the problem reproduce in non-Mu WordPress? If it is Mu specific then please open a ticket at ​http://trac.mu.wordpress.org

item.title: Ticket #3557 (Wordpress stripping TR formatting from tables and deleting the ...) created
item.dc:creator: johnol
item.description:
I believe this is related to ticket #2992 but specific to WordPress Mu. There is a problem in the WordPress MU engine as it saves a post where it strips out not only the table formatting but also the items that were formatted.

I CAN build and save tables - just can't implement features such as background color for cells, etc.

This seems to be with the engine itself rather than with TinyMCE because the same behavior is observed with Xinha4WP as well as with the Rich Text Editor completely disabled and simply working directly with the HTML.

As table formatting seems to work OK in WordPress using no Rich Text Editor, using the Rich Text Editor, and using Xinha4WP, I'm assuming that there's some extra "magic" that WordPressMU is doing during a save which is removing this extra formatting.

Being able to offer tables is critical - and having WordPress *delete* entire blocks of text during the saving is not good.

item.title: Ticket #3545 (Content-Type header case sensitive) updated
item.dc:creator: johnleach
item.description: Doh, I see now that I was looking at only one section of the RFC (duh). It does state that they are case-insensitive so this is definitely a bug in WP-Cache (which I've reported). Thanks Mark.

item.title: Ticket #3547 (Misspelling in readme.html in branches/2.0 as well) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
Milestone changed

Trying to keep 2.0.7 to the bare minimum, but will fix for 2.0.8

item.title: Ticket #3545 (Content-Type header case sensitive) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
Owner, Status, Milestone changed

RFC2616 explicitly says that HTTP headers are case-insensitive. That said, it doesn't hurt us to capitalize them as they are presented in the RFC. Well-behaved clients won't care and lazy clients will more likely than not use the capitalization that the RFC uses.

The only problem I see is that some of the instances in WP of "Content-type" are in external libraries like Snoopy or TinyMCE. Changing those may present an added burden for maintenance.

At any rate, 2.2 territory.

item.title: Ticket #3555 (Some servers escape $_SERVER['HTTP_IF_NONE_MATCH'], breaking 304 Etag ...) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
Owner, Status, Description, Summary changed

Oops, mistyped the header name... it is $_SERVER['HTTP_IF_NONE_MATCH']

item.title: Ticket #3555 (Some servers escape $_SERVER['HTTP_IF_NONE_MATCH'], breaking 304 Etag ...) created
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
I've found that on some servers, $_SERVER['HTTP_IF_NONE_MATCH'] is backslash-escaped. WP then comes along and escapes it again, so your Etag looks like:

\\\"65e8871191351efa4678a314e040fa34\\\"

Then, before checking, WP runs stripslashes() once, which gets you to:

\"65e8871191351efa4678a314e040fa34\"

It then tries to compare the Etags, but fails, because of the backslashes. Thus, a 304 is not served, content is served, and bandwidth is wasted.

Patches coming.

Also resolves issue where focus is not returned to editor after closing any popup. This could use testing in other browsers.

Both of these patches have been sent to tinymce dev.

item.title: Ticket #3534 (Hide password in setup-config.php) updated
item.dc:creator: xmarcos
item.description:
Milestone changed

Replying to Nazgul:

-1 for the current proposed solution.

If you use a field of type password, you should use a confirmation password field as well, because people can't see their password typos this way.

Also, because this is a enhancment and not a bugfix, I'm pushing it out of scope for 2.1.

For the third time i think, this is the DATABASE PASSWORD, ok?

You won´t forgot it because you already have it, otherwise you won't get Wordpress running, trust me, no database password, no Wordpress.

Regarding the confirmation, it is NOT A USER-SET PASSWORD. Again you have the password already, if you mistype it, you get and sql connection error.

Now, I remember why I avoid posting tickets, people just don't take the time to read descriptions.
